div.l: Whatt woll ȝe do while that it is in hande
By god ryȝt bi þe hopper woll y stande
Quod Iohn and see how the corn̄ gas in
Ȝit saw y neuer by my fadirkyn
How the hopper wagges to and fra
Aleyn answerde Iohn wilt þou swa
Thānne wille y stanne binethe by my croun
And se how þe meles a doun̄
In to þe trouȝ that sshallshall sall be my disport
For Iohn in faith y may be of your͗e sort
I am as yuell amiller͗e as ar ȝe
This millere smyled of hir nycite
And thouȝt all this is but for a wile
Thei wene than noman may him bigile
But bi my thrift ȝet shall I blere her ye
For all þe slyȝt of hir philosophie
The more queynte crekes that they make
The more whanne I stele wolle I take
In stede of flour͗e yit wolle I yeue hem bren
The gretest clerkys ben not wisest men
As whilome to þe wolf spak the mar͗e
Off all hir art ne counte y nouȝt a tar͗e
¶ Out of the dore he wente priuily
Whānne that he saw his tyme softely
He lokith vp and doun̄ til he haue founde
The clerkes hors wher͗e he stod y bonde
Be hynde þe mille vnder a leuesel
And to the hors he goth him faire and wel
He strepith of þe bridil ryȝt anon̄
And whānne þe hors was loos he gynnyþ to gon̄
Toward þe fen þer͗e wilde maris renne
And furth wiþ we he thurwȝ thikke and þurwȝ thenne
The miller͗e goth ageyn no word ne seyde
But doth his note and with his clerkys pleyde
Til that hir corn̄ was fayr͗e and well Igrounde
And whānne þe mele was sakked and I bounde
This Iohn goth oute and fyndith his hors away
He gan to crie herow and welaway
